title: How to Make a Holographic Vase

steps.headline: Clean your vase.
steps.description: Choose a vase with straight walls. Wash it with soap and water, then pat it dry with a clean towel. Wipe it down with rubbing alcohol. This will get rid of any oils that might prevent the paint and vinyl from sticking. From now on, try to hold the vase only from the inside. Avoid using "bell-shaped" vases. It will be difficult to wrap the vinyl around them.

steps.headline: Protect the inside of your vase with newspaper and painter's tape.
steps.description: Tear off a strip of painter's tape, and apply it to the inside rim of your vase. Stuff the vase with scrunched up newspaper. You will be painting your vase to help the colors show up better. If you want a translucent vase instead, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Paint your vase with flat, white spray paint.
steps.description: This will make your vase opaque and help the color show up better. Apply the paint using 2 to 3 thin, even coats; let each coat dry first before applying the next. Applying the paint in lots of thin layers will help reduce drips and puddles. If you want a translucent vase instead, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Let the paint dry completely.
steps.description: This should only take about 20 minutes, but you might want to refer to the label on your paint can. Once the paint is dry, you can remove the painter's tape and newspaper.

steps.headline: Measure and cut the holographic vinyl.
steps.description: Measure the height and circumference of your vase. Draw a rectangle on the back of your vinyl, making it slightly bigger than your measurements.

steps.headline: Start applying the vinyl to the vase.
steps.description: Lay the vase down on its side. Peel away some of the backing from the vinyl, and press it down onto the side of your vase.

steps.headline: Continue applying the vinyl to the vase.
steps.description: Working a little bit at a time, continue peeling the backing away from the vinyl and pressing the vinyl onto the vase. Smooth out any air bubbles as you go.

steps.headline: Trim off the excess vinyl from the top and sides of your vase.
steps.description: Keeping the vase down on its side, use a craft blade to cut the excess vinyl from the top and bottom edges. Discard the excess vinyl.

steps.headline: Use the vase.
steps.description: If you have not already, remove the painter's tape and newspaper. Fill the vase with water, then add some flowers into it. You can also use it to hold fake flowers instead.

steps.headline: Get some DVDs.
steps.description: You can use old, scratched up DVDs that no longer, or you can use blank DVDs instead. You can also use CDs instead, but DVDs seem to be more colorful and holographic.

steps.headline: Heat the DVD up using a hairdryer.
steps.description: Set the DVD down onto a heat-safe surface, or hold it by the edges. Blow dry the DVD using the hottest setting on you hairdryer for a few minutes.

steps.headline: Use a butter knife to pry apart the DVD.
steps.description: A DVD is composed of two layers with a thin, holographic film in the middle. You want the holographic film to stick to the back/clear layer of the DVD, not the front/decorated part. Work slowly and carefully. The DVD will be hot, so be careful. Discard the top, colored part of the DVD. Save the bottom part with the holographic film.

steps.headline: Cut up the DVD into small pieces.
steps.description: You can cut it into squares, rectangles, triangles, or random pieces. It would be a good idea to have a variety of shapes and sizes, especially if your vase is round.

steps.headline: Clean your desired vase.
steps.description: Wash the vase using soap and water, then pat it dry with a clean towel. Wipe down the vase one last time using rubbing alcohol. This will remove any oils that might prevent the glue from sticking. From now on, try to handle the vase only from the inside. Square or rectangular vases will be easier to work with than round vases. The shape is entirely up to you, however.

steps.headline: Paint your vase with flat, white spray paint.
steps.description: Your DVD tiles will be a little translucent, so this will help the colors show up better. Apply 2 to 3, thin coats of flat, white spray paint to you vase. Let each layer dry before applying the next. Allow the vase to dry completely before moving on. For a neater finish, line the rim of your vase with painter's tape, then stuff it with newspaper. Remove both once the vase dries.

steps.headline: Start gluing the tiles to the vase.
steps.description: You can use hot glue, but it would be better if you used a glue meant specifically for glass. Start at one end of the vase, and work your way to the other. You can leave small gaps between the tiles, or make them flush against one another.

steps.headline: Let the glue dry.
steps.description: How long this takes depends on what type of glue you used. Hot glue sets up very quickly, but many glass glues take much longer.

steps.headline: Fill the gaps in, if desired.
steps.description: This is not necessary, but it will help hide any glue and give you a more mosaic effect. You can fill the gaps in using black or white puff paint/dimensional fabric paint. You can also use grout instead. For a more interesting effect, try silver puff paint/dimensional fabric paint instead. If you are using grout, be sure to mix it according to the instructions on the package. Apply the grout to the vase, then wipe it off with a damp cloth.

steps.headline: Let the puff paint or grout dry before using the vase.
steps.description: Again, how long this takes depends on what you used. Both can take several hours to dry, but some types of grout can take several weeks. Once everything is dry, your holographic vase is ready to use! Fill it with water, then add some freshly-cut flowers into it.

text: Using Vinyl Film Clean your vase. Choose a vase with straight walls. Wash it with soap and water, then pat it dry with a clean towel. Wipe it down with rubbing alcohol. This will get rid of any oils that might prevent the paint and vinyl from sticking. From now on, try to hold the vase only from the inside. Avoid using "bell-shaped" vases. It will be difficult to wrap the vinyl around them. Protect the inside of your vase with newspaper and painter's tape. Tear off a strip of painter's tape, and apply it to the inside rim of your vase. Stuff the vase with scrunched up newspaper. You will be painting your vase to help the colors show up better. If you want a translucent vase instead, you can skip this step. Paint your vase with flat, white spray paint. This will make your vase opaque and help the color show up better. Apply the paint using 2 to 3 thin, even coats; let each coat dry first before applying the next. Applying the paint in lots of thin layers will help reduce drips and puddles. If you want a translucent vase instead, you can skip this step. Let the paint dry completely. This should only take about 20 minutes, but you might want to refer to the label on your paint can. Once the paint is dry, you can remove the painter's tape and newspaper. Measure and cut the holographic vinyl. Measure the height and circumference of your vase. Draw a rectangle on the back of your vinyl, making it slightly bigger than your measurements. Start applying the vinyl to the vase. Lay the vase down on its side. Peel away some of the backing from the vinyl, and press it down onto the side of your vase. Continue applying the vinyl to the vase. Working a little bit at a time, continue peeling the backing away from the vinyl and pressing the vinyl onto the vase. Smooth out any air bubbles as you go. Trim off the excess vinyl from the top and sides of your vase. Keeping the vase down on its side, use a craft blade to cut the excess vinyl from the top and bottom edges. Discard the excess vinyl. Use the vase. If you have not already, remove the painter's tape and newspaper. Fill the vase with water, then add some flowers into it. You can also use it to hold fake flowers instead. Using DVD Tiles Get some DVDs. You can use old, scratched up DVDs that no longer, or you can use blank DVDs instead. You can also use CDs instead, but DVDs seem to be more colorful and holographic. Heat the DVD up using a hairdryer. Set the DVD down onto a heat-safe surface, or hold it by the edges. Blow dry the DVD using the hottest setting on you hairdryer for a few minutes. Use a butter knife to pry apart the DVD. A DVD is composed of two layers with a thin, holographic film in the middle. You want the holographic film to stick to the back/clear layer of the DVD, not the front/decorated part. Work slowly and carefully. The DVD will be hot, so be careful. Discard the top, colored part of the DVD. Save the bottom part with the holographic film. Cut up the DVD into small pieces. You can cut it into squares, rectangles, triangles, or random pieces. It would be a good idea to have a variety of shapes and sizes, especially if your vase is round. Clean your desired vase. Wash the vase using soap and water, then pat it dry with a clean towel. Wipe down the vase one last time using rubbing alcohol. This will remove any oils that might prevent the glue from sticking. From now on, try to handle the vase only from the inside. Square or rectangular vases will be easier to work with than round vases. The shape is entirely up to you, however. Paint your vase with flat, white spray paint. Your DVD tiles will be a little translucent, so this will help the colors show up better. Apply 2 to 3, thin coats of flat, white spray paint to you vase. Let each layer dry before applying the next. Allow the vase to dry completely before moving on. For a neater finish, line the rim of your vase with painter's tape, then stuff it with newspaper. Remove both once the vase dries. Start gluing the tiles to the vase. You can use hot glue, but it would be better if you used a glue meant specifically for glass. Start at one end of the vase, and work your way to the other. You can leave small gaps between the tiles, or make them flush against one another. Let the glue dry. How long this takes depends on what type of glue you used. Hot glue sets up very quickly, but many glass glues take much longer. Fill the gaps in, if desired. This is not necessary, but it will help hide any glue and give you a more mosaic effect. You can fill the gaps in using black or white puff paint/dimensional fabric paint. You can also use grout instead. For a more interesting effect, try silver puff paint/dimensional fabric paint instead. If you are using grout, be sure to mix it according to the instructions on the package. Apply the grout to the vase, then wipe it off with a damp cloth. Let the puff paint or grout dry before using the vase. Again, how long this takes depends on what you used. Both can take several hours to dry, but some types of grout can take several weeks. Once everything is dry, your holographic vase is ready to use! Fill it with water, then add some freshly-cut flowers into it.
sentences: Using Vinyl Film Clean your vase.
Choose a vase with straight walls.
Wash it with soap and water, then pat it dry with a clean towel.
Wipe it down with rubbing alcohol.
This will get rid of any oils that might prevent the paint and vinyl from sticking.
From now on, try to hold the vase only from the inside.
Avoid using "bell-shaped" vases.
It will be difficult to wrap the vinyl around them.
Protect the inside of your vase with newspaper and painter's tape.
Tear off a strip of painter's tape, and apply it to the inside rim of your vase.
Stuff the vase with scrunched up newspaper.
You will be painting your vase to help the colors show up better.
If you want a translucent vase instead, you can skip this step.
Paint your vase with flat, white spray paint.
This will make your vase opaque and help the color show up better.
Apply the paint using 2 to 3 thin, even coats; let each coat dry first before applying the next.
Applying the paint in lots of thin layers will help reduce drips and puddles.
If you want a translucent vase instead, you can skip this step.
Let the paint dry completely.
This should only take about 20 minutes, but you might want to refer to the label on your paint can.
Once the paint is dry, you can remove the painter's tape and newspaper.
Measure and cut the holographic vinyl.
Measure the height and circumference of your vase.
Draw a rectangle on the back of your vinyl, making it slightly bigger than your measurements.
Start applying the vinyl to the vase.
Lay the vase down on its side.
Peel away some of the backing from the vinyl, and press it down onto the side of your vase.
Continue applying the vinyl to the vase.
Working a little bit at a time, continue peeling the backing away from the vinyl and pressing the vinyl onto the vase.
Smooth out any air bubbles as you go.
Trim off the excess vinyl from the top and sides of your vase.
Keeping the vase down on its side, use a craft blade to cut the excess vinyl from the top and bottom edges.
Discard the excess vinyl.
Use the vase.
If you have not already, remove the painter's tape and newspaper.
Fill the vase with water, then add some flowers into it.
You can also use it to hold fake flowers instead.
Using DVD Tiles Get some DVDs.
You can use old, scratched up DVDs that no longer, or you can use blank DVDs instead.
You can also use CDs instead, but DVDs seem to be more colorful and holographic.
Heat the DVD up using a hairdryer.
Set the DVD down onto a heat-safe surface, or hold it by the edges.
Blow dry the DVD using the hottest setting on you hairdryer for a few minutes.
Use a butter knife to pry apart the DVD.
A DVD is composed of two layers with a thin, holographic film in the middle.
You want the holographic film to stick to the back/clear layer of the DVD, not the front/decorated part.
Work slowly and carefully.
The DVD will be hot, so be careful.
Discard the top, colored part of the DVD.
Save the bottom part with the holographic film.
Cut up the DVD into small pieces.
You can cut it into squares, rectangles, triangles, or random pieces.
It would be a good idea to have a variety of shapes and sizes, especially if your vase is round.
Clean your desired vase.
Wash the vase using soap and water, then pat it dry with a clean towel.
Wipe down the vase one last time using rubbing alcohol.
This will remove any oils that might prevent the glue from sticking.
From now on, try to handle the vase only from the inside.
Square or rectangular vases will be easier to work with than round vases.
The shape is entirely up to you, however.
Paint your vase with flat, white spray paint.
Your DVD tiles will be a little translucent, so this will help the colors show up better.
Apply 2 to 3, thin coats of flat, white spray paint to you vase.
Let each layer dry before applying the next.
Allow the vase to dry completely before moving on.
For a neater finish, line the rim of your vase with painter's tape, then stuff it with newspaper.
Remove both once the vase dries.
Start gluing the tiles to the vase.
You can use hot glue, but it would be better if you used a glue meant specifically for glass.
Start at one end of the vase, and work your way to the other.
You can leave small gaps between the tiles, or make them flush against one another.
Let the glue dry.
How long this takes depends on what type of glue you used.
Hot glue sets up very quickly, but many glass glues take much longer.
Fill the gaps in, if desired.
This is not necessary, but it will help hide any glue and give you a more mosaic effect.
You can fill the gaps in using black or white puff paint/dimensional fabric paint.
You can also use grout instead.
For a more interesting effect, try silver puff paint/dimensional fabric paint instead.
If you are using grout, be sure to mix it according to the instructions on the package.
Apply the grout to the vase, then wipe it off with a damp cloth.
Let the puff paint or grout dry before using the vase.
Again, how long this takes depends on what you used.
Both can take several hours to dry, but some types of grout can take several weeks.
Once everything is dry, your holographic vase is ready to use!
Fill it with water, then add some freshly-cut flowers into it.
